title: Between 7 July 2020 and the end of the season, how many NBA players residing at the Walt Disney World complex will test positive for COVID-19, according to the NBA?
preds: Down to four teams in the bubble. No sign of any recent issues other than the Daniel House incident, which the NBA handled swiftly and decisively.
Has any NBA player tested positive for Coronavirus? Nevermind two tested positive on July 7.
Families have started coming into the bubble.

Looks like there has been a resolution to continue the playoffs.
https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/29752941/nba-players-decide-resume-playoffs
Many more will test positive, but 0-4 will be reported on.

As long as the NBA keeps releasing testing results with 0 positive cases, I'll keep revising this downward. Turns out that covid can be controlled if you create an environment with strict protocols and the participants have strong incentives to follow them. Who knew?  *narrator* 
"We all knew"
Unlikely the virus gets in and if it dies the procedures in place should be able to stamp it out quickly
2 more weeks since I updated with 0 new cases

Honestly, incredibly surprised by the NBAs success. Given that the number of teams is only going to decrease from here on out and the success so far, I think it'll remain very limited the number of players who will get COVID.
Adjusting down based on the success the NBA has had
Would lose face if their experiment doesn’t work. Probably gonna give another injury as reason when somebody doesn’t play.

Regardless of statistical modeling and NBA and proxy spinners, there is too much money at stake to forecast a "real" or "transparent" answer. There are new testing methods being developed frequently, like this one link https://www.theverge.com/2020/8/15/21370153/covid-saliva-test-authorization-fda-nba-yale So it is really a crapshoot. At least NBA "bubble" has yet to find a player sneaking a girlfriend into his room disguised as another player...

Would guess that with visitors there will be at least one slip up. Since they are testing every day I don't think it will get far before a strict shelter in room is enforced. I would guess that the NBA will be quick to remove guests if it threatens the season.

Of 342 players, zero so far. https://www.nba.com/article/2020/08/12/nba-nbpa-coronavirus-test-results-official-release Seeing how well the players guest policy work out would be interesting. https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nba/2020/08/12/nba-players-coronavirus-visits-bubble-playoffs/3355587001/ Obviously a lot is on stake to keep the games going.
Adjusting given that so far zero have been inflicted. This means the Bubble works well and we should look at it from a rather optimistic point of view.

Given the players on the same team share so much of physical space in proximity, unlikely that if a couple of players get positive test results that majority of the rest of their teams doesn’t test positive.
Again, with zero positive tests. This is really impressive so far.  https://www.nba.com/article/2020/08/05/august-5-nba-nbpa-coronavirus-test-results-official-release
Adjusting downwards given the news today that there have been 0 cases for a third straight week. (There were 2 cases the first week which is why I have 0% for 0 cases)

The success so far of no positive tests is remarkable. That said, we are only one week into actually playing games and the Finals are scheduled for the beginning of October. There's a lot of time in there so I'm not confident that this trend will continue. I am lowering my likelihood of a large outbreak though.
Rebalancing lower to account for the apparent success of maintaining the bubble and the league’s appropriate response to the Lou Williams “just pickin’ up some wings” incident.

Working on the premise that the disease is highly infectious, particularly in an indoor setting, I think it's unlikely this runs any middle ground, if 1 player brings sars-cov-2 onto a court, there's a good chance we skip straight to bucket 4. So we'll have a successful bubble or a blow out.
They are using quarantine to the max.

https://www.forbes.com/sites/tommybeer/2020/07/29/commissioner-adam-silver-nba-seasons-would-cease-completely-if-outbreak-occurred/#a49fe934f16c Question is how many will it take to call the season over.

2 cases have already been diagnosed. 0 cases in the latest round of testing, means the policies they have in place have been able to contain any outbreaks they have within the bubble, even with scrimmages beginning. However games are starting up so there will be more contact between players and as the lockdown continues, players are more likely to get restless and break rules.

First week in the bubble: 2 cases
Second week: 0 cases
Thrid week: 0 cases
Adjusting downwards

Hard to predict until games start up and we see how tightly the bubble holds with the passage of time. Spreading this equally(-ish) across the remaining 4 buckets until some actionable data presents itself.
I think that even with the rules they have in place, the egos of the players will move them to take risks and then spread the disease within the bubble.

There are 22 teams and about 15 players per team which makes about 330 players.  Even 10% of that is already 33 players. Judging by the amount of staff and families that may come in and out of the bubble before it ends, 10% of the players seems like a minimum value.

Fact is if even one player gets the virus, going by how it's spreading, it's gonna lead to several more cases due to the nature of the game. So I feel it's gonna be either 0 or a lot. I am not sure what is my definition of a lot, but still.
Also, due to rapid and regular testing protocols, if there's a case, even if the person is asymptomatic, it will be detected, unlike outside the bubble (unless a person goes in for a test).
I think they are doing a great job in the bubble, but perfection is very difficult
The bubble the NBA has created to protect its players and staff appears to be working. I expect it will continue to work for the remainder of the season.

Given the success keeping the virus out of the bubble so far, I'm weighing "0" and "between 1-7 higher" more than I would given the state of the pandemic in the US. Least likely though, is 8-14. If a player does catch it, given the tight game schedule and the incubation period it seems unlikely that an outbreak would stay between those numbers given the contact between players.

Zero positive tests after 10 days is encouraging, and will be to the players as well who *hopefully all recognize what is at stake. Taking an optimistic view that now they are safely bubbled they will behave [shaking my head at my own optimism as I reread my comment]
As of July 23 7 players have tested positive since July 7
I believe there will be some cases but once they appear adherence to protocols will be better.

22 teams, 17 (15+2) players per team. A total of 374 players.  I think the league itself expects some amount of spread within the players (hence the +2 of backup players). And while most of the players, team staff and support staff is in the bubble - there is always the prospect of infection being carried in by a Disney employee. Hence my baseline estimate.

Increased odds for 1-7 and 8-14, decreased for 15-21 and 22+ given the news of 0 cases since July 13th. I mentioned before that the early weeks are most important in containing the virus, and the NBA has done a good job so far. The bubble has been created, the only question is whether it can be maintained for 3 months.

Changing my prediction significantly. My original prediction was predicated on players being able to leave the campus somewhat, employees not taking seriously, etc. Here's where things have changed for me:
1. By all accounts, the NBA players, employees, and NBA as a whole are taking this extremely seriously.
2. In the first week after players arrived, there have been zero positive tests. You would have thought if there was going to be any wave, you would have at least seen 1-2 tests come in as escapes.
3. If we don't see any big waves early, the next big chance is when families come. That will though be when there are only 8 teams left, who all will see the possibility of a finals run in their future. The big counterpoint is that any one case could propagate quickly on the court, and once teams are playing each other (not themselves) then there will be multiple teams in jeopardy. Still weighing 1-7 low, but it feels like the chance of a low number has greatly increased this week.
Zero tested positive since first tests.

Lowering my forecast because of the smoothness in which other sports have been able to restart. I still think 22 or more is most likely because of the way covid spreads--in groups. Here is the best list I've been able to find of the players that have tested positive so far. I don't believe any of them count for this question because they were not in the bubble. https://www.slamonline.com/nba/nba-coronavirus-covid-list/

It's been 10 days since teams arrived and only 2 cases have been reported. I was impressed with the plan the NBA had and the execution seems to be strong as well. The best time for the virus to spread was the past week while players and staff were arriving from all over the country, but it does not seem to have done so. I still expect sporadic cases as there are almost 3 months for players/staff to be stupid, but it doesn't seem likely that the virus will spread widely.

Continuing to backoff a bit on this one. It seems like a significant number of players tested positive going into the bubble and reports from in the bubble seem to suggest that things are being taken extremely seriously.
Updating this the reflect the current strain of covid19 that spreads much more readily than previous versions.
It will run rampant once one player or staff is tested positive.

The only information to update my predictions since yesterday is that players are using the anonymous hotline to report protocol violations. IMO this slightly reduces the chance that the virus spreads widely, but I'm only updating by 1%.
Keeping the bones of my forecast and responding to the crowd.
Two tested positive in first round before being released from quarantine.  https://bleacherreport.com/articles/2900096-why-nba-players-coaches-are-confident-the-bubble-is-working

19 players have tested positive but only 2 in the bubble. Both of them were in quarantine when they tested positive. Players who haven't followed protocol (ie ordered in food) have had extended quarantines placed on them. If the number of cases doesn't jump in the next few days that would be very encouraging that the measures the NBA put in place are working.
Dropping off a little bit. The bubble sounds like it’s fully in place and there are many who haven’t travelled due to previously testing positive.
It's in Florida which is a Covid heavy state. There's too many people involved in the bubble to hope to keep it out. I believe somewhere between 8-21 the NBA will cancel the whole competition.
With more thinking, I'm thinking it is increasingly possible that more than 22 test positive and the nba hasn't canceled the season by that point.

3 players have already tested positive since July 7, according to the NBA. The bubble will be staffed by low paid service workers in Florida, subcontracted by Disney, not the NBA. A bunch of young athletes still suffer from the magical thinking of adolescence, and will be unable over months to observe all the rules.

Teams arrived in Orlando from July 7-9. There are 18 current active cases (players and staff) with the most recent case being announced on July 9th. None of these players/staff traveled to Orlando. It is encouraging that we have not seen any positive tests in the days following the teams' arrival. Even if no cases were brought in there are still opportunities for the virus to spread as players can get approval to leave the campus and eventually some guests will be allowed in (though there are strict measures in place for these events). The MLS already has at least 22 cases (don't know the exact number) which is discouraging, but their problems began soon after teams arrived and they were not as strict as the NBA (1 day quarantine on arrival vs 3-4). https://www.reddit.com/r/nba/comments/hfinjk/discussion_running_list_of_confirmed_covid19/
https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/29321006/in-documents-nba-details-coronavirus-testing-process-orlando-campus-life
https://sports.yahoo.com/coronavirus-mls-nba-sports-return-protocols-025336665.html
https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2020/07/10/mls-bubble-is-massive-undertaking-how-it-fares-will-tell-us-lot-about-sports-return/
400-450 players, at least 5% of which will test positive.

I think for me there are three possible routes:  i) the number of cases is low and the season goes as the NBA hopes
ii) the number of cases is grows quickly and the NBA quickly calls off the season before more than 22 players have positive tests.
iii) the number of cases grows rapidly and passes 22 quickly.  There are around 300 players going to the "bubble." (24 teams, about 12 players per team). So, 22 or more cases suggests a pretty large outbreak - about 2 teams worth of players. I think the season will be called off before it reaches that level. So, I'm going go with the crowd essentially, but under on the 22 or more just because it seems almost impossible that more than 22 players get it without the season being called off previously.  I think some clarification regarding the term "end of the season" would be nice. If they put the season on pause, and then later cancel it, would positive cases in between the pause and the cancellation count? Similarly, if the season never actually resumes would the cases count at all? I'm basically "end of season" to mean a team is crowned champion or the season is fully cancelled but it's a little unclear to me.
When cases start showing up, the season will be called off, but it won't be quickly enough to stop before it gets to 20.  Major League Soccer already has two full teams impacted.

This is a spicy one due to considerations such as: -Will an indefinite/long-term suspension count as the "end of the season" for the purposes of this? If a suspension period does not, that could present an extremely long testing window. (Assuming that for at least some meaningful period of a suspension, players would choose/be compelled to remain "residing" in the bubble.) I have requested a clarification from admins on this question. For now, I am assuming that only an official "season is over" announcement will count.
-How many positives before they shut it down? (I'm assuming that they will pause games with even one or a few cases, but wouldn't cancel without a broader cluster.  That said, during such a pause, many more cases would likely be discovered.) To the extent that 16 players have tested positive in recent days, and NBA is forging ahead, I assume that level of positive tests falls within NBA's "expected" realm for any given point in time.  If that is the case, the total number of positives over a period of time could be substantially higher without prompting them to pull the plug on the season. I appreciate @ikresnak's comment here:  "MLS had a similar testing protocol and 10 players tested positive on single team. Basketball courts are 1) indoors, 2) smaller, and 3) the game requires much more physical contact." Thanks to @Bobbiekar52 for tip on the most helpful article I read on this. [1] Excerpt: "The occurrence of a small or otherwise expected number of COVID-19 cases will not require a decision to suspend or cancel the resumption of the 2019-20 season."  Big picture, I think the specific framing of this question sets up a high likelihood of an extended window between the first positives and the official "end", skewing the probability very heavily toward the high side. [1] https://www.wlrn.org/post/pro-basketball-returning-florida-coronavirus-surges#stream/0
Infections are inevitable. Once there are more than 10, players will start to panic and opt out of the season. The league will have to respond promptly at that point.
people think they are immune, they will not be able to keep the players out of the nightlife in the area

Hedging, but I don't see how this works out. MLS had a similar testing protocol and 10 players tested positive on  single team. Basketball courts are 1) indoors, 2) smaller, and 3) the game requires much more physical contact.
https://www.wlrn.org/post/pro-basketball-returning-florida-coronavirus-surges#stream/0 The NBA is anticipating some and has plans in place

Reasons
1. A number of players have already tested positive. 
2. Because each team has been practicing together,  means there may be more on each team who are asymptomatic who will test positive later.  
3. And once the season starts they will spread to to other teams. And there are 100s of NBA staff the players have to interact with.
4. Each teams roster is 15 players. 
5. 30 NBA teams. Even if 1 players on each team test positive. It's over 22.
let's get off this corona cycle

https://www.bostonglobe.com/2020/07/02/sports/25-nba-players-have-tested-positive-covid-19/
Question: would they stop the season if three players tested positive and exposed others? Season stops at three but maybe more test positive afterward? 7.1% infection rate among players so far. This is initial forecast.

The locker room and team sports (heavy exertion with hard breathing, close quarters) are a perfect recipe for rapid spread of COVID-19.  Once a player or two tests positive, despite frequent testing and attempts at isolation, the increase in infected players will be very fast.  By the time 10 or more players test positive, the teams and the league will reconsider the wisdom of continuing.  By that time, it is possible that more than 15 players will already be infected, but things will shut down quickly.
ADJUSTING. for the phrase - according to the NBA.

The NBA is fully expecting there will be positive tests. The question is how many.  Reasons to expect 22 or more:
1. The NBA isn’t in a true bubble where no one is in or out, the staff will be distanced to some extent but it will be impossible to prevent contact. Additionally players aren’t fully quarantined themselves. 
2. Cases in Florida are on the rise making this more difficult.
3. There are 17 players going for 22 total teams. That’s a 6% total positive case recording to hit 22. Additionally, there will be backup players in the bubble as well for teams. 
4. Some players will already have COVID and travel to Florida with the teams, and not test positive until they get there.  Case against:
1. Players take this extremely seriously and don’t leave the bubble.
2. Really good protocols are in place for the staff so they can’t get any of the players sick.

15 players per team, 30 franchises = 450 active players under usual circumstances, (I guess 22 teams this year.)
This doesn't include team staff, NBA staff and the family that encounter the players. (Note: 17 players per team now, more info: https://sports.yahoo.com/2020-nba-season-restart-teams-010534942.html) Rough estimate that 0.849% of the US has been confirmed to have or have had C-19, so let's say that 3 players minimum test positive. In close quarters, non-distant game play and team coordination, with an R0 of 2-2.5 we can expect 6-7 players minimum. I don't know how they expect to contain this. Players on the bench sit shoulder to shoulder, so good luck getting 6' between 20-30 players coaches and staff. Then, if you haven't watched basketball before, feel free to google it. Lots of contact, lots of heavy breathing, lots of fluids. So this should be interesting. Starting at "8-14" in realization that I tend to underestimate all things C19
0% chance of "0"
Definitely at least 1.
15 and up are quite possible. I'll adjust.

15 players per team, 30 franchises = 450 active players under usual circumstances, (I guess 22 teams this year.)
This doesn't include team staff, NBA staff and the family that encounter the players. Rough estimate that 0.849% of the US has been confirmed to have or have had C-19, so let's say that 3 players minimum test positive. Lots of contact, lots of heavy breathing, lots of fluids. So this should be interesting. Starting at "8-14" 
0% chance of "0"
Definitely at least 1.
15 and up are quite possible.

The NBA is trying to do everything in their power to prevent COVID19 from spreading, it will be hard, but not impossible. That’s why I’m giving 0 zero players a slightly better than one in ten chance of happening.  https://www.cnbc.com/2020/06/17/nba-coronavirus-plan-smart-technology-to-keep-players-safe.html?&qsearchterm=nba%20keeping%20players%20safety

I'm focusing on the middle options because, based on what's happened with the PGA Tour, somebody is going to test positive.  However, if the time comes where 20 players test positive, the season will be shut down.

Possibility :
-they will keep quiet.
-they will say a few and stop, then they will not further add positive testers too nba testing positives?
-possibility, they have to stop multible times...

22 teams. 12-15 players per team.  Staff at hotel, restaurants, etc. will be "screened" but are not a part of the "bubble." TBH, the chances of everyone observing the 100 plus pages of rules Over 3 months is low. While designed to minimize potential issues, it will not eliminate the possibility. https://www.msn.com/en-us/sports/nba/spurs-derozan-unhappy-with-nba-bubble-rules/ar-BB16htKU?li=BB15ms5q
